page.title: 06LEIGHTON NARROW GAUGE TRAINS
page.content: This two foot gauge railway is a true working line, built in 1919 to carry sand from the quarries to the main line of the London and North Western Railways. Apart from its opening day the railway had never provided a passenger service until 1967 when a group of enthusiasts formed a society to save the line from extinction and to open it to the public for the first time. Since then they have rebuilt the track, built their own coaches, station and engine sheds, installed signalling and safety equipment and acquired several unique and historic locomotives. The line passes through varied surroundings from its terminus at Pages Park, past on of many sand quarries in the area, through new housing estates and industrial areas to open country side. The return trip, five and a half miles, takes 70 mins.
